events.event_description: Western U.S. hydropower generation fell to its lowest level in 22 years, dropping 11% from the previous water year to 141.6 million megawatthours.
events.citation: According to preliminary data from our Electricity Data Browser, the least hydropower was generated in the western United States during the 2022–23 water year (October 1 through September 30) since at least 2001. Western region hydropower generation dropped by 11% from the previous water year to 141.6 million megawatthours (MWh).

events.event_description: A severe heat wave in May 2023 caused rapid snowmelt in the Northwest region, leading to reduced hydropower generation for the rest of the water year.
events.citation: In May 2023, a heat wave that drove temperatures 30°F above normal affected the region, melting the snowpack rapidly. Water flows in May were high, but much of the water supply needed for generation during the summer months melted during the May heat wave.

events.event_description: Washington state experienced a 23% decline in hydropower generation, while Oregon's generation fell by more than 20% in the 2022-23 water year.
events.citation: In the 2022–23 water year, 23% less hydropower was generated in Washington than the water year before, totaling 62.3 million MWh. Hydropower generation in Oregon also fell by more than 20% in the 2022–23 water year.

events.event_description: California experienced record snowpack levels and nearly doubled its hydropower generation due to atmospheric rivers bringing heavy precipitation from December 2022 to March 2023.
events.citation: From December 2022 to March 2023, a series of atmospheric rivers drenched parts of the western United States, especially California, with record rain and snow. Information from the California Department of Water Resources shows that last winter's snowpack in the state was higher than any other reading since records began in the mid-1980s.

events.event_description: Glen Canyon Dam increased hydropower generation by 27%, while Hoover Dam generated 11% less electricity due to water conservation efforts at Lake Mead.
events.citation: Hydropower generation at the Glen Canyon Dam increased by 27% during water year 2022–23 compared with the water year before. However, water conservation efforts downstream at Lake Mead reduced water releases. The Hoover Dam, which forms Lake Mead, generated 11% less electricity in the 2022–23 water year than it did in the previous water year.
